title: Monocular vision (sight in only one eye) and driving

details.description: You don't need to tell DVLA if you have monocular vision and can meet the visual standards for driving
details.body:
You may need to tell DVLA if you have monocular vision.

You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.

It may take several months for you to adapt safely to driving with one eye. In particular, your ability to judge distances accurately may be affected and you may not be so aware of objects to each side of you.

Car or motorcycle licence

You don’t need to tell DVLA if you’re still able to meet the standards of vision for driving detailed in leaflet ‘VIS1’.

Download ‘INF188/1 - A guide to standards of vision for driving cars and motorcycles’ (PDF, 213KB)

If you have a health condition in your functioning eye, please check the rules for that condition in health conditions and driving.

If you have any doubt about whether you can meet the requirements, consult your GP, optician or eye specialist.

Bus, coach or lorry licence

You must tell DVLA. Fill in form V1V and send it to the address on the form.

Download ‘V1V - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 345KB)
